description: From Middle English ȝemanry, yemandry, yema[n]ri, yemanrye, yomandrye, yomanry; equivalent to yeoman +‎ -ry.

entries.meaning: (historical) A class of small freeholders who cultivated their own land.
examples: The enfranchised yeomanry began to feel an instinct for dominion.

entries.meaning: A British volunteer cavalry force organized in 1761 for home defense and later incorporated into the Territorial Army.
